questions.text: A 33-year-old man comes to the physician because of gradually worsening bilateral foot pain for the past 2 months. The pain used to only occur after long walks and subside with rest. For the past week, the pain has been continuous and associated with burning sensations. He has also had transient painful nodules along the course of the leg veins for 4 months that resolve spontaneously. The patient is wearing an ankle brace for support because of a sprained left ankle that occurred 3 months ago. His mother was diagnosed with protein C deficiency as a teenager. He has smoked 2 packs of cigarettes daily for 15 years and does not drink alcohol. Vitals signs are within normal limits. Examination shows ulcers on the distal portion of his left great, second, and fifth toes. The feet are cool. Pedal pulses are barely palpable. Ankle-brachial pressure index is 0.3 in the left leg and 0.5 in the right leg. Which of the following interventions is most likely to decrease the risk of amputation in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In patients with peripheral arterial disease, the use of compression stockings is contraindicated if the ankle-brachial index is < 0.6 because it can exacerbate lower limb ischemia. Instead, they are indicated in chronic venous insufficiency (CVI), which can manifest with pain in the lower limb and lower limb ulcers. However, CVI causes a “dragging” pain that is worsened by prolonged standing and relieved by walking or lying down with the lower limbs elevated, and venous ulcers typically occur over the shin and medial malleolus. Moreover, the skin surrounding the ulcers would be hyperpigmented and/or thickened, and a history of lower limb edema and/or varicose veins would be present. Also, CVI typically occurs in elderly patients.

B) INCORRECT:

Chronic mechanical, extrinsic blood flow obstruction can cause limb ischemia or even compartment syndrome, which would manifest with progressively worsening pain despite immobilization, sensory deficits, as well as out-of-proportion pain on passive movement in the affected limb. This patient has clinical signs of vasculitis, and painful legs, bilaterally.

C) INCORRECT:

Peripheral artery bypass surgery or other revascularization procedures (e.g. angioplasty) usually cannot be performed in TAO because TAO affects distal small and medium-sized arteries, which are not amenable to revascularization procedures.

D) CORRECT:

Smoking is the single most important risk factor for TAO. The exact mechanism by which smoking causes TAO is unknown, but direct endothelial cell toxicity from the components of tobacco is presumed to play a role. Complete cessation of smoking and other tobacco products is, therefore, the most important therapeutic measure to prevent gangrene and amputation.

E) INCORRECT:

In patients with chronic limb-threatening ischemia, anticoagulation with unfractionated heparin or low molecular weight heparin (e.g., enoxaparin) is not useful. Anticoagulation should instead be used in a patient with acute limb ischemia (ALI), which can manifest similarly with painful cold limbs bilaterally if a saddle thrombus occurs. A family history of protein C deficiency is also a risk factor for thrombosis. However, with ALI, the onset of symptoms would be acute (as the name suggests!), the pedal pulses would be absent rather than decreased, and paralysis of the lower limbs would be expected. Moreover, patients with protein C deficiency would typically present with venous rather than arterial thrombosis.

F) INCORRECT:

Steroid therapy, e.g., with prednisolone, is commonly indicated to treat vasculitides with systemic features such as respiratory symptoms (e.g. Churg-Strauss, granulomatosis with polyangiitis) or renal involvement (e.g. polyarteritis nodosa, microscopic polyangiitis). It is not useful in the treatment of TAO where the disease process is primarily confined to the distal extremities. This patient lacks symptoms of systemic vasculitis and is not a candidate for steroid therapy.

G) INCORRECT:

Iloprost therapy can help relieve the limb pain associated with TAO. However, a different measure is more important to prevent amputation of the limb.

H) INCORRECT:

Statins are a crucial component in medical therapy for patients with atherosclerotic peripheral artery disease (PAD), which can manifest similarly with limb claudication, decreased pulses, digital ulcers, and a low ABI. However, atherosclerotic PAD typically occurs in elderly patients, and superficial thrombophlebitis is not a feature of atherosclerotic PAD. Progression of TAO cannot be prevented by statins because it is not an atherosclerotic process.

I) INCORRECT:

To prevent secondary Raynaud phenomenon, which commonly occurs in patients with TAO, protection of fingers and toes from cold temperatures is recommended. This intervention, however, only helps reduce the symptoms associated with painful vasospasms and does not address the underlying cause.
questions.hint: Claudication pain, features of chronic limb-threatening ischemia (rest pain for > 2 weeks, decreased peripheral pulses, cold extremities, digital ulcers, very low ankle-brachial pressure index), and history of migratory superficial thrombophlebitis (transient, painful nodules along the course of the veins) in a young, male patient indicate thromboangiitis obliterans (TAO).

questions.text: A 38-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of a painful rash affecting his left foot. For the past 2 years, he has had recurrent episodes of color changes in his fingers when exposed to the cold; his fingers first turn white and then progress to blue and red before spontaneously resolving. He has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 20 years. His blood pressure is 115/78 mm Hg. Physical examination shows multiple tender, dark purple nodules on the lateral surface of the left foot with surrounding erythema that follow the course of the lateral marginal vein. There are dry ulcers on the tip of his right index finger and on the distal aspect of his right hallux. Serum lipid studies show no abnormalities. Biopsy of the dorsalis pedis artery will most likely show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Granulomatous inflammation with narrowing of the vessel lumen
Segmental thrombosing inflammation with sparing of the internal elastic lamina
Calcification of the tunica media with foam cells and fibrous cap formation
Intraluminal fibrin clot predominantly composed of red blood cells
Transmural inflammation with fibrinoid necrosis of the vessel wall

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Granulomatous inflammation with narrowing of the vessel lumen is a distinguishing feature of Takayasu arteritis. This medium-to-large vessel arteritis is associated with Raynaud phemomenon, which is seen in this patient. However, Takayasu arteritis most commonly affects middle-aged women of Asian descent and manifests with fevers, polyarthralgias, visual impairments, and hypertension, none of which are seen in this patient.

B) CORRECT:

Segmental thrombosing inflammation of small and medium-sized vessels that spares the internal elastic lamina is the characteristic histologic finding in TAO. TAO most commonly occurs in male smokers < 45 years of age and manifests with migratory thrombophlebitis, Raynaud phenomenon, and digital ischemia with intermittent claudication. Eventually, limb-threatening ischemia may develop, which can result in rest pain of the distal extremities, peripheral pulselessness, and/or gangrene with autoamputation of digits.

Smoking is the single most important risk factor for TAO. The exact mechanism by which smoking causes TAO is unknown, but direct endothelial cell toxicity from the components of tobacco is presumed to play a role. Complete cessation of smoking is, therefore, the single most important therapeutic measure to prevent gangrene and amputation.

C) INCORRECT:

Calcification of the tunica media with foam cell infiltration and fibrous cap formation is a distinguishing feature of atherosclerosis. Atherosclerosis is most commonly seen in elderly men with a significant smoking history. In addition, luminal narrowing due to formation of atherosclerotic plaques is the pathophysiology underlying peripheral artery disease, which can cause digit ulcers, as seen in this patient. However, atherosclerosis would not explain this patient's Raynaud phenomenon and superficial thrombophlebitis. Moreover, atherosclerosis is strongly associated with arterial hypertension and dyslipidemia, none of which are seen here.

D) INCORRECT:

Intraluminal fibrin clots that are predominantly composed of red blood cells are known as red thrombi, which are commonly seen in deep venous thrombosis. Patients with DVT often report unilateral leg erythema and swelling with notable tenderness that is worse upon palpation. DVT does not explain this patient's Raynaud phenomenon, digital ulcers, or the waxing and waning timecourse of his symptoms.

E) INCORRECT:

Transmural inflammation with fibrinoid necrosis is a distinguishing histologic feature of polyarteritis nodosa. Skin ulcerations can occur due to obstruction of medium-sized arteries (e.g., digital arteries), ultimately causing ischemia in the fingertips. However, patients with PAN also present with hypertension (due to renal involvement), polyneuropathy, and signs of gastrointestinal distress (e.g., nausea, vomiting), none of which are seen in this patient. Moreover, PAN is not commonly associated with Raynaud phenomenon.
questions.hint: This patient's signs of digit ulceration, superficial thrombophlebitis (painful nodules), and Raynaud phenomenon (vasospasm of the fingers in response to cold exposure), together with his significant smoking history, are suggestive of thromboangiitis obliterans (TAO).

questions.text:
A 50-year-old man presents with severe pain in the distal second digit on the right hand and the third digit on the left hand; both digits have become dusky and purple during the past 2 days. He has a several-month history of bilateral finger pain that worsens in the cold. He reports no fevers, chills, night sweats, other joint pain, or rash. He has smoked at least one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 35 years; he has never used recreational drugs.
On examination, both affected digits are dusky and cool. The skin of the other digits is not thickened, and examination of the nail-fold capillaries is normal. Radial pulses are palpable, but an Allen test indicates compromised blood flow in the radial arteries bilaterally.
Laboratory testing reveals a normal complete blood count, normal chemistry panel, normal erythrocyte sedimentation rate, normal C-reactive protein level, and negative blood cultures. Tests for antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies, antinuclear antibody, cryoglobulins, complement components C3 and C4, antiphospholipid antibodies, and other hypercoagulable states are negative. Because of concern for cocaine-induced vascular injury, urine testing for cocaine has been sent repeatedly during the past 12 months and has been consistently negative.
Chest radiography and both transthoracic and transesophageal echocardiography are unremarkable.
What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Thromboangiitis obliterans, also known as Buerger disease, is an inflammatory disease of the arteries and veins that occurs almost exclusively in people who smoke. Men are more commonly affected than women, and disease onset is typically in the fourth or fifth decade of life. The most common clinical presentation is digital ischemia, leading to ulceration, gangrene, or both. Migratory superficial thrombophlebitis can be seen in the early phase of the disease. A positive Allen test (meaning that the patient does not have an adequate dual blood supply to the hand) can suggest the diagnosis but is also abnormal in other causes of arterial occlusion. The mainstay of treatment is smoking cessation; in the absence of smoking cessation, patients can experience digital ischemia severe enough to lead to digital gangrene and need for amputation (or even autoamputation of affected digits).

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in a patient with a history of cigarette smoking who has occlusive arteriopathy leading to digital ischemia is thromboangiitis obliterans.

B) INCORRECT:

Systemic sclerosis (scleroderma) can cause digital ischemia, but affected patients typically have thickened skin (sclerodactyly) and a positive test for antinuclear antibody. Sclerodactyly may not be apparent early in the course of systemic sclerosis, but the nail-fold capillaries are typically abnormal in multiple digits.

C) INCORRECT:

A systemic vasculitis — such as polyarteritis nodosa, cryoglobulinemia, microscopic polyangiitis, or granulomatosis with polyangiitis (formerly referred to as Wegener’s) — typically manifests with elevated levels of inflammatory markers and other symptoms.

D) INCORRECT:

A systemic vasculitis — such as polyarteritis nodosa, cryoglobulinemia, microscopic polyangiitis, or granulomatosis with polyangiitis (formerly referred to as Wegener’s) — typically manifests with elevated levels of inflammatory markers and other symptoms.

E) INCORRECT:

Endocarditis is unlikely with a normal transesophageal echocardiogram and negative blood cultures. Bacterial endocarditis usually features constitutional symptoms, elevated inflammatory markers, and positive blood cultures. Noninfectious (marantic) endocarditis is usually associated with a hypercoagulable state.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents with a 2-month history of episodic fingertip pain that worsens with cold exposure. He reports a tender, cord-like nodule that appeared on his forearm 3 weeks ago and resolved spontaneously. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 10 years. Physical examination shows diminished radial pulses bilaterally and a small ulceration on his left index fingertip. Laboratory results show normal erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR), C-reactive protein (CRP), and autoantibodies. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Tobacco cessation counseling and vascular surgery referral
Echocardiography for cardiac source of emboli

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- In a young man who smokes and has digital ischemia, migratory superficial thrombophlebitis, normal inflammatory markers, and no atherosclerotic risk factors, thromboangiitis obliterans is the likely underlying condition. Complete tobacco cessation is the most important therapeutic measure, and vascular surgery referral is essential for further evaluation and management.

B) INCORRECT:

Anticoagulation is not the primary treatment for thromboangiitis obliterans. The inflammatory, nonatherosclerotic nature of this condition requires management focused on eliminating the underlying trigger.

C) INCORRECT:

While calcium channel blockers may provide symptomatic relief for vasospastic symptoms, they do not address the underlying pathophysiology and are not the most critical initial intervention in this patient's condition.

D) INCORRECT:

While cardiac emboli should be considered in the differential diagnosis, the combination of young age, smoking history, migratory thrombophlebitis, and bilateral distal pulse abnormalities makes thromboangiitis obliterans more likely than embolic disease.

E) INCORRECT:

Corticosteroids are not indicated for thromboangiitis obliterans. Normal ESR and CRP help differentiate this condition from other vasculitides that might benefit from anti-inflammatory therapy.
